item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Policy Makers Could See Opportunity in China’s Rise
item.description: “It would be a mistake to view increased frictions as the result of inattention or clumsy policy,” says Ely Ratner, deputy director of the Asia-Pacific Security Program at the Center for a New American Security.
item.category: Center for a New American Security
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Ely Ratner, a senior fellow at the Center for a New American Security, believes the Obama administration wants to remain focused on concrete initiatives with China.

item.title: U.S. Tells U.N. Panel of Steps to Revise Interrogation Policy
item.description: The acting State Department legal adviser told a United Nations panel that monitors torture that the United States had used cruel treatment after the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: World Religion: Latin America Is Losing Its Catholic Identity
item.description: The Roman Catholic Church’s claim on the region is lessening as a younger generation turns to Protestantism, a Pew study found.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL PAULSON
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mass in July in El Pedregal, a small town along the Guatemala-Mexico border. A survey found that 69 percent of Latin American adults said they were Catholic, down from an estimated 90 percent for much of the 20th century.

item.title: In Climate Deal With China, Obama May Set 2016 Theme
item.description: The landmark agreement to cut greenhouse gas pollution is a bet by the president and Democrats that voters are far ahead of Washington’s warring factions.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Under the Ships in the Suez Canal
item.description: Invasive species are crossing into the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: By JULI BERWALD

item.title: Decree by Sisi Could Lead Egypt to Free Journalist
item.description: The decree enabling the president to deport non-Egyptians convicted of crimes could aid an imprisoned journalist, Peter Greste.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Web of Incentives in Fatal Indian Sterilizations
item.description: People who took part in a sterilization drive in the state of Chhattisgarh that led to 13 deaths described an assembly-line atmosphere with little regard for hygiene.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Tefé Journal: Fishermen in Brazil Save a River Goliath, and Their Livelihoods
item.description: Efforts to save the pirarucu, one of the world’s largest freshwater fish, have been a success while offering a strategy for fending off a broader freshwater extinction crisis.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fisherman pulled in a pirarucu at Lago do Macaco, or Monkey Lake, near Maraã, Brazil.

item.title: Health Officials Reassess Strategy to Combat Ebola in Liberia
item.description: As the rate of new infections has slowed, American and Liberian officials are debating whether to shift money that was planned for the centers into other programs to combat future outbreaks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Air Force personnel working last month to set up a 25-bed hospital near Monrovia, Liberia.

item.title: Climate Accord Relies on Environmental Policies Now in Place
item.description: The United States and China should both be able to meet the stated goals by aggressively pursuing policies that are largely underway, analysts said.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN and JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: World Briefing: Azerbaijan: Armenian Copter Downed
item.description: Azerbaijan shot down and destroyed an Armenian military helicopter in the Nagorno-Karabakh region on Wednesday, the countries’ defense ministries said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Fruitful Visit by Obama Ends With a Lecture From Xi
item.description: The Chinese and American presidents’ news conference laid bare stubborn differences over issues like press freedom.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China attended a ceremony Wednesday at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing before holding a news conference.

item.title: In China, Blunt Talk to Reporters on Access
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, appeared to state as policy something long hinted: a link between unfavorable news coverage and denials of reporters’ visas.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Obama Aims to Lift the Global Economy, and Maybe Himself
item.description: Mr. Obama will arrive at an international economic meeting in Australia hoping to press European and Asian leaders to get their economies moving again — and perhaps buoy his own presidency.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: The Treasury chief Jacob J. Lew says the world is looking to America “to drive the global recovery.”

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Pentagon Rebuts Claim on Drone
item.description: Iran’s claim to have not only replicated but test-flown its version of a sophisticated bat-winged American spy drone captured in late 2011 is a gross exaggeration, the Pentagon said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: 9 Held in Antiterrorism Raids
item.description: The police in the Cologne area detained nine men early Wednesday and searched at least 20 homes in raids against people suspected of supporting terrorism.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Outbreak in Mali Eclipses Early Success
item.description: The West African nation of Mali, which just beat its first outbreak of Ebola, has confirmed a second one that is larger and more threatening, global health authorities said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A police officer on guard outside the Pasteur Clinic in Bamako, Mali, where a patient with the country's second confirmed case of Ebola died.

item.title: Fears Rise as Russian Military Units Pour Into Ukraine
item.description: The NATO confirmation comes after days of reports from Ukrainian and European officials of tanks crossing into eastern Ukraine in scenes reminiscent of Russia’s invasion of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Russian tanks on a road to Donetsk. Russian officials deny plans to intervene in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Pakistan Seeks Dissidents’ Arrest
item.description: Warrants were issued for the opposition leaders Imran Khan and Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri for their part in leading a protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Open Source: Journalists Detained for Talking Politics in Cairo Cafe
item.description: Talking politics with a foreigner in a cafe in Cairo now strikes some Egyptians as grounds for arrest.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Landing on a Comet, a Mission Aims to Unlock the Mysteries of Earth
item.description: The ambitious mission succeeded, despite a potential showstopper problem, when a signal arrived at Darmstadt, Germany, just after 11 a.m. Eastern time.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: Journalists filmed as a giant screen showed members of the European Space Agency celebrating news of the touchdown.

item.title: Jean-Claude Juncker Breaks Silence Over Luxembourg Tax Issues
item.description: The former prime minister of Luxembourg, now the president of the European Commission, denied that his “ambition was to organize tax evasion in Europe.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, right, at a meeting of the European Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: In the Words of Xi Jinping: Unraveling an Ancient Saying
item.description: The Chinese president’s idiom appeared to warn foreign journalists that if they want to avoid visa difficulties, it is up to them to satisfy Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: In Shake-Up, Iraqi Premier Replaces 36 Commanders
item.description: It was the first public effort by Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi to put his mark on the security forces battling Islamic State militants.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: For Some, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Falls Short of Expectations in Myanmar
item.description: Human rights advocates and even members of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s political party are raising questions about her performance in the broader political arena.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at the opening of a school near Yangon last month, four years after emerging from house arrest as a celebrated democracy champion.
